senses.dict_examp: We need to open up the overseas markets.
senses.lear_examp: It is suggested that one of our English as a Foreign Language lessons should be filmed, as there are some 100 overseas students who are from over 30 countries in our school.

senses.sense: someone who owns something
senses.dict_examp: Are you the owner of this car?
senses.lear_examp: The owner was an old woman who lives alone in a big house with her pet animals.

senses.sense: to deal with and control a problem or feeling
senses.dict_examp: I admire the way she has overcome her difficulties/problems and made a success of her life.
senses.lear_examp: Trying to overcome my fear, I was slowly going toward the dangerous stranger.

senses.sense: to suddenly have too much of  a feeling
senses.dict_examp: She was overcome by emotion.
senses.lear_examp: When she got in her house she was overcome by a sense of wrath and started screaming and crying.

senses.sense: for or during the night
senses.dict_examp: an overnight stop in Paris
senses.lear_examp: We will stay in our tents overnight and get up early in the morning to reach the next camping site.

senses.sense: very quickly or suddenly
senses.dict_examp: Change does not happen overnight.
senses.lear_examp: I am aware of the fact that it is not at all an easy path nor  is it something that can happen overnight.

senses.sense: to do or use too much of something
senses.dict_examp: I went to the gym yesterday, but I think I overdid it a bit.
senses.lear_examp: On the other hand, people usually overdo it and prefer making use of the modern technology to meeting a friend.

senses.sense: to guess or think that something is or will be bigger or better than it really is
senses.dict_examp: They overestimated her ability to do the job.
senses.lear_examp: In spite of the progress achieved in promoting the social status of women, one should not overestimate the significance of these achievements to ordinary women's careers.

senses.sense: If a container overflows, the things inside it start to come out because it is too full, and if the contents of a container overflow, they come out because it is too full.
senses.dict_examp: The sink overflowed, and there's water all over the floor!
senses.lear_examp: As a result of relentless rain the river had broken its banks and overflowed violently.

senses.sense: If a place is overflowing, there are too many people in it.
senses.dict_examp: The square was overflowing with people trying to see the queen.
senses.lear_examp: The prisons are overflowing, society is losing out in many ways.

senses.sense: to have a lot of a quality or emotion
senses.dict_examp: Her father was overflowing with pride as he watched her receive her award.
senses.lear_examp: She felt overflowing with indignation as if he had been rude to her.

senses.sense: containing too many people or things
senses.dict_examp: an overcrowded classroom/prison
senses.lear_examp: As you arrive about midday, the trams are likely to be overcrowded.

senses.sense: to fill something with too much or more then it should contain
senses.dict_examp: Don’t overload the washer or it won’t work properly.
senses.lear_examp: Secondly the buses and trains are mostly overloaded.

senses.sense: to give someone too much to do
senses.dict_examp: All the staff are completely overloaded.
senses.lear_examp: I was also overloaded with work and had many doubts about joining the group at all.

senses.sense: when someone has more of something than they can deal with
senses.dict_examp: We are suffering from data overload here.
senses.lear_examp: Will we get to the point of "information overload"?

senses.sense: because of
senses.dict_examp: The concert has been cancelled owing to low ticket sales.
senses.lear_examp: To start with, it is a great idea to change rooms because they are too crowded, owing to the fact that there a lot of people.

senses.sense: a form of oxygen that exists high in the atmosphere
senses.dict_examp: the ozone layer
senses.lear_examp: There is probably no child who hasn't heard about the holes in the ozone layer or the greenhouse effect.

senses.sense: If you are overdrawn, you have taken more money out of your bank account than you had in it.
senses.dict_examp: Your account is overdrawn.
senses.lear_examp: In other words their expenditure is much more than their income. They get into debt and are mostly overdrawn.

senses.sense: a gas that is in the air and that animals need to live
senses.dict_examp: an oxygen tank
senses.lear_examp: Everybody needs oxygen and trees produce oxygen.

senses.sense: Someone who is overworked has to work too much.
senses.dict_examp: We're overworked and underpaid.
senses.lear_examp: People are overworked and often choose fast food for dinner.

senses.sense: when you own something
senses.dict_examp: Do you have any proof of ownership for this car?
senses.lear_examp: Converting all of this into private ownership is a long term process.

senses.sense: too heavy or too fat
senses.dict_examp: He's still a few pounds overweight.
senses.lear_examp: In England the majority of people are either overweight or underweight.

senses.sense: a bird with a flat face, large eyes, and strong curved nails, which hunts small mammals at night
senses.dict_examp: We heard an owl hooting in the night.
senses.lear_examp: I could hear an owl hooting in the tree nearby.

senses.sense: to go past a vehicle or person that is going in the same direction
senses.dict_examp: We were overtaken by a red sports car.
senses.lear_examp: Of course it is easier for a bike to overtake the cars in traffic jams.

senses.sense: to go past something by being a greater amount or degree
senses.dict_examp: US sales have been overtaken by sales in Europe.
senses.lear_examp: This however was projected to be overtaken by people coming from the 35-49 year old bracket by 2006.

senses.sense: in general rather than in particular, or including all the people or things in a particular group or situation
senses.dict_examp: The overall situation is good, despite a few minor problems.
senses.lear_examp: Overall these two restaurants are worth going to for nice meals.

senses.sense: extra time that you work after your usual working hours
senses.dict_examp: He's been working a lot of overtime lately.
senses.lear_examp: You can't go on living like this, chasing around and always being pressured by your work and all this overtime.

senses.sense: a short description giving the most important facts about something
senses.dict_examp: I'll just give you an overview of the job.
senses.lear_examp: Moreover, I would recommend a student and a teacher to be interviewed, so that we can provide a better overview of the institution itself, with both the opinions of those who teach and those who learn here.

senses.sense: knowledge of the general features of something
senses.dict_examp: Having spent some time there, she had a good overview of the market.
senses.lear_examp: As my main interest was to get an overview of the current market situation, I was simply impressed by the variety of companies that you've presented.

senses.sense: more than a particular amount, number, or age
senses.dict_examp: Most of the bikes cost/are over $500.
senses.lear_examp: We have to dance in a school and over two hundred people will watch us.

senses.sense: covering something or someone
senses.dict_examp: Put a blanket over you to keep warm.
senses.lear_examp: Wear an apron over your clothes.

senses.sense: above or higher than something
senses.dict_examp: The sign over the door said "Exit."
senses.lear_examp: Besides that, you have voted for the construction of a new bridge over the main street.

senses.sense: across from one side of something to the other, especially by going up and then down
senses.dict_examp: She jumped over the gate.
senses.lear_examp: I most enjoyed it when we were cycling over the hills, because there weren't any people and it was peaceful and quiet.

senses.sense: everywhere in a particular place
senses.dict_examp: Soon the news was all over town.
senses.lear_examp: The people in the class are from all over the world.

senses.sense: during a particular period of time
senses.dict_examp: I was in Seattle over the summer.
senses.lear_examp: I could make up for the work I missed over the weekend, if that's alright with you.

senses.sense: on the other side of
senses.dict_examp: Their house is just over the river.

senses.sense: in this/that place
senses.dict_examp: Put your bags down over there.
senses.lear_examp: How is everything over there?

senses.sense: using
senses.dict_examp: They spoke over the phone.
senses.lear_examp: She laughed over the phone, and said "It's really like you".

senses.sense: in control of or teaching someone or something
senses.dict_examp: Parents want to have control over their children.
senses.lear_examp: Fortunately, my parents do not wield authority over me and my siblings like dictators.

senses.sense: connected with or about
senses.dict_examp: It's stupid arguing over something so trivial.
senses.lear_examp: The teams themselves suffered from these money problems: recently strikes broke out in basketball teams in the U.S. when players began to argue over money.

senses.sense: more than a particular amount or level
senses.dict_examp: People who are 65 years old and over can get half-price tickets.

senses.sense: from one side or place to another
senses.dict_examp: She leaned over and kissed me.
senses.lear_examp: He came over to me and we talked a while.

senses.sense: finished
senses.dict_examp: I'll be glad when the semester is over.
senses.lear_examp: David smiled triumphantly and said, "It is all over!"

senses.sense: describes the way an object moves or is moved so that a different part of it is facing up
senses.dict_examp: She turned another page over.
senses.lear_examp: A big truck had turned over and blocked the road and there was no other way for us to go, so we had to wait.

senses.sense: happening or done many times
senses.dict_examp: I read the article over and over.
senses.lear_examp: I've been searching in newspapers over and over again and finally after a couple of days I found something.

senses.sense: repeated from the beginning
senses.dict_examp: We had to start all over again.
senses.lear_examp: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again.

senses.sense: to do something difficult or unpleasant  as soon as you can so that you do not have to worry about it any more
senses.dict_examp: I got all my apologies over and done with at the beginning of the meeting.
senses.lear_examp: Not to mention that he knew that he had to get his degree over and done with before he started making serious decisions.

senses.sense: If a feeling or situation overwhelms someone, it has an effect that is too strong or extreme.
senses.dict_examp: She was overwhelmed by the excitement of it all.
senses.lear_examp: I am sure the students from the acting classes will be overwhelmed by the grandeur of the 200-seat theater.

senses.sense: very strong in effect or large in amount
senses.dict_examp: She felt an overwhelming urge/desire/need to tell someone about what had happened.
senses.lear_examp: Second, the overwhelming majority of your staff members speaks English only, which poses a big problem for those passengers who can not speak English.

senses.sense: If two subjects or activities overlap, they are the same in some way.
senses.dict_examp: Although our job titles are different, our responsibilities overlap quite a lot.
senses.lear_examp: Of course, these two motivations can be overlapping and ideally they do overlap.

senses.sense: to have a view of something from above
senses.dict_examp: Our hotel room overlooked the harbor.
senses.lear_examp: I had a delicious lunch in a cozy restaurant overlooking the Cote d'Azur.

senses.sense: to not notice or consider something
senses.dict_examp: His film was nominated for an Oscar, but Reiner himself was overlooked as best director.
senses.lear_examp: Of course, man's basic needs cannot be overlooked and a certain amount of wealth can be put to very good use, wisely to provide for oneself and one's family and home.

senses.sense: belonging to or done by a particular person or thing
senses.dict_examp: All of the students have their own dictionaries.
senses.lear_examp: We have to bring our own paints.

senses.sense: belonging to someone or something
senses.dict_examp: I'll have a home of my own someday.
senses.lear_examp: I also bought a cupboard of my own, so that I need not share with my sister.

senses.sense: alone
senses.dict_examp: I like living on my own.
senses.lear_examp: On Wednesday morning I went on my own to see the Vatican.

senses.sense: without any help
senses.dict_examp: Ryan can't get into his shirt on his own - he's just a baby!
senses.lear_examp: Maybe I can do the missing work on my own.

senses.sense: to be as successful as other people or things
senses.dict_examp: Alison could always hold her own in political debates.

senses.sense: to have something that legally belongs to you
senses.dict_examp: We own our house.
senses.lear_examp: It is owned by a Japanese owner.

senses.sense: to hear what someone is saying when they are not talking to you
senses.dict_examp: I overheard him telling her he was leaving.
senses.lear_examp: I once overheard a remark from a person who had just been in Italy.

senses.sense: to have to pay money back to someone
senses.dict_examp: I owe Janet ten dollars.
senses.lear_examp: Please tell me how much I owe you for that.

senses.sense: to have to give something to someone because they deserve it
senses.dict_examp: I think you owe  me an explanation/apology.
senses.lear_examp: I owe you a favor.

senses.sense: to have something or achieve something because of someone or something else
senses.dict_examp: The museum owes much of its success to the present generation of young artists.
senses.lear_examp: Many restaurants, bars and gift shops owe their existence to the fact that visitors to our country enjoy the view of the river and its surroundings.

senses.sense: over the side of a boat and into the water
senses.dict_examp: Wait! Something fell overboard.
senses.lear_examp: My diary is lost - it fell overboard on my way home.

senses.sense: to do something too much, or to be too excited about something
senses.dict_examp: I think I went overboard cooking this dinner – there is enough to feed a dozen people.
senses.lear_examp: While no one should restrict their eating habits to the point eating is no longer a pleasure, but rather a chore, it is important not to go overboard, completely disregarding the advice of nutrition experts.
